project_name: NEW 1 STOREY RESIDENCE FOR DAVE AND CORY MATTHEWS
gravity_system: Girder Truss, Loadbearing Walls, Concrete Footings
other_materials: P.T. Lumber, Rigid Insulation, Metal Roofing, Wood Siding
key_elements: ICF Walls, Deck Ledger Connection, Concrete Piers, Steel Column Footing
overall_building_description: The building's structural system is meticulously designed to ensure both gravity and lateral load resistance. The gravity load path begins with the girder truss system, which spans across the roof, transferring loads to the loadbearing walls. These walls are constructed using insulated concrete forms (ICF), providing both structural support and thermal insulation. The ICF walls are reinforced with 10M and 15M rebar, ensuring adequate shear and bending resistance. The load path continues from the walls to the concrete footings, which are reinforced as per plan with 15M rebar dowels spaced at 4'-0" on center, providing a solid foundation on undisturbed soil or bedrock. The lateral load resistance is primarily provided by the ICF walls, which act as shearwalls, effectively transferring lateral forces to the foundation. The building section 1/A6 reveals the integration of a ridge beam and vented soffit, which are critical for attic ventilation, adhering to the OBC requirements for attic venting at a ratio of 1/300. The steel beam and column connection detail, referenced as 2/A6, specifies the use of a 3/8" end plate and a 1/2" x 5 1/2" x 8" top plate, secured with 3/4" A325 bolts, ensuring a robust connection capable of transferring loads efficiently. The steel column footing detail, 2/D1, highlights the use of a steel base plate anchored to the footing, with a minimum of 6" compacted granular fill, ensuring stability and load distribution. The concrete pier detail, 4/D1, specifies the use of Simpson brackets and Hilti Kwik anchors, providing a secure connection between the column and the beam. The deck ledger connection, detailed in 5/D1, illustrates the integration of the main floor system with the deck, using ledger boards and ICF walls for support. The foundation plan notes emphasize the importance of frost protection, with footings insulated where 4'-0" ground cover is not possible, as per detail 1/D1. The site plan notes mandate a minimum 2% slope for drainage, with eavestroughs connected to storm sewers, ensuring effective water management. The assemblies schedule provides comprehensive specifications for wall, floor, ceiling, and roof assemblies, ensuring compliance with design criteria and performance requirements. The wall assemblies, such as EW1 and EW2, incorporate 2x6 studs at 16" o.c., with R20 batt insulation and a 6 mil poly vapor barrier, ensuring thermal efficiency and moisture control. The roof assemblies utilize pre-engineered wood trusses, with options for asphalt shingles or metal finishes, providing flexibility in design and aesthetics. The construction details, such as the ICF opening detail 3/D1, specify the placement of rebar around window and door openings, ensuring structural integrity and load transfer. The building's design adheres to the Ontario Building Code (OBC), with specific references to sections 9.6.6 for door resistance and 9.30.6 for concrete reinforcement, ensuring compliance with safety and performance standards. The project incorporates advanced materials and construction techniques, such as the use of ACQ-rated fasteners for treated wood and the application of rigid insulation for energy efficiency. The detailed specifications and construction notes provide a comprehensive framework for the successful execution of the project, ensuring structural integrity, safety, and compliance with regulatory requirements.
